¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	In the manner of performing a causticization on an inguinal hernia [inguinal dislocation].
Caput XLII.	When cold and dampness occur within, prohibited is due to im
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When mucous secretions descend to the penis [mucosae pulmonalis usque ad pecten Anchae effunduntur], and they cause death from that place: it is a sign of such an illness, for when comparing with one another (the male patient), he founds his leg stretched on this side. Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I placed this section on suturing up to the foot.

Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin this section, it is necessary that the son of these parents be added to this chapter as well; for what we find herein which concerns destruction through burning (cauterization), originated firstly from terror over death in the initial chapters regarding mortality and injury.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And for this reason it is necessary that care be taken more earnestly here; because the operations found within these chapters—which often result from bleeding during surgery (as mentioned previously), due to wound laceration, or incision above an abscess—involve fear and horror. And in all of them there lies death: cutting through flesh, piercing bone, opening sinuses with cauterization instruments that lead straight into the brain; these together are associated with terrors, which always result in multiple fatalities among their authors.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I advise you not to let the doubts about this section prevail over us here; because when they fall upon men of our art with similar sickness, it often affects them similarly.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei. Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And when the sickness is due to fear, that indeed represents death itself.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And it is from this that the author gives his own poison and tells you to take it with hope for your health; but in reality, its disease is harmful.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore there shall not be a need to agree with him who comes from that way; for his manner of doing so is harmful and detrimental.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And let your caution be more earnest than greed and gluttony.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume anything from that without certain knowledge which medicine has achieved among those to whom it led a praiseworthy continuation of life.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And hasten to the care for all sick people's curatives, with diagnosis and advice aiming at what is beneficial for health.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in that there lies also a help to you concerning the acquisition of fame and glory, as well as memory and praises.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	Let God or His son imbue you with your own intelligence and not remove from you guidance and inspiration; for that is within his power.

And I indeed ordered this chapter distinguishing by chapters according to what had preceded in the Chapter of Cauterii from leeches up to feet: that it may benefit you who seek such things and provide for those who need them.

¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	The treatment for his fall onto stone.
Caput VI.	Chapter Six.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Everything that falls into the ground is one of four species: either a stone like substance or stones similar to it (as iron), as well as grapes and beans; also things flowing like water and vinegar, and other similars; or else something animate.

When then the stone falls onto the ground, whether it is of the same kind as stones that are not melted nor grow on earth; expose (it) to the sun: if you see a stone at noon exposed in the earth, then from its burning-oil or resin will distill something.

Thereafter administer the extraction of it and make him cough with discomfort and stuff his nostrils upon breathing out (postnascitur) as soon as he puts on an ear trumpet made from cloth or wool, stretched up to a large cup in hand.

This is how they were done in Albucasis’ time.

Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	But if the stone that falls into the ear is from one of those which grow and expand inside (caused by internal pressure or "inflammation"): then extract it out!
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	However if you do not obey me about the way to remove something: take a light and delicate pad of this very kind as an alternative.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And administer the incision of that particular kind made with stones which fall into ears: do not make this when you think it is unnecessary to remove a stone already wet in earwax (as if through an otoscope): until one or more pins are placed firmly inside its interior, and then extracted using small tweezers; as we have said before. Note that the removal of these stones from ears involves suction similar to what is described herein above because they cannot be removed otherwise without painful procedures like cutting with surgical instruments! The use of such techniques could lead not only physical but also psychological trauma for patients who might fear invasive surgeries due their sensitivity or other health issues. A better, less intrusive method would ensure patient comfort and respect while providing effective treatment – avoiding any unnecessary discomfort during the procedure should always be a priority in medicine! Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If then she goes out through that, it is good.

¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	Concerning the extraction of teeth using gold wire:
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter XXXIII.
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	When the teeth anteriorly suffer concussion and commotion by percussion, or as it were: and he who is weak cannot hold back that which touches him with these means so that nothing falls downward; treated them you did then with stopping pills not for curing but rather to keep quiet until after death passes away; yet never does gold change into silver.
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And let the thread be both delicate and coarse according to quantity that it carries between teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	And the form of retention is that you receive a thread and introduce double its length between two healthy teeth; if there are only one tooth involved then treated with movement on both ends, or more than two in case they move towards each other until reaching an agreement at another part of his mouth.
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	Thereafter continue treating the texture until to that part where you had intervened; pull with your hand delicately and wisely so as not to remove too much: And let the constriction of the thread at its roots be such as it does not rot, i.e., decay near them (the teeth).
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Thereafter cut off the superfluous ends of the threads with foresides; aggregate and bend them both ways as you can handle so that they are in a circular form, then wrap around each one: turning to their respective teeth without hurting speech by causing movement between healthy tooth and diseased tooth. After this let such treatment be released while something remains (treatment).
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	If he abandons it or if it breaks: then pull the remaining teeth with a thread again and let him stay in such way for that time (duration of treatment).
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	And this is the manner of teeth and figure in threading for two healthy tooth pairs as well as a pair with movement: just like you see from afar (in vision).
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	And sometimes it happens that one tooth or two come back after cavities have formed in the same location as previously described and just like we narrate them above remain; only they return if there is a skilled, careful, and experienced artificer (surgeon).
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	And whenever there is prepared a tooth-shaped wax or model of the jawbone with teeth outlines from within them: and it takes its shape just like that of the dental formations mentioned; and then, as previously explained, this thing remains fixed in place by being compressed tightly together at one spot for an extended period.

Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor. Science (knowledge), which includes that the act of castration is forbidden according to our law and for this reason I have authorized myself not to remember it in my book: and such a memory is only necessary if due to two reasons or circumstances.

Si ergo os matricis est apertum, tunc intromittat manum in profundum matricis, et quaerat cum ea caput, et attrahat ipsum cum digitis usque ad os matricis: deinde intromittat in eo uncinum unum, aut uncinos duos, et attrahat ipsum cum eo.	If the mother's mouth is open: then insert hands deep into her womb and ask when she will push with it, pulling from within until you feel that which is inside comes out; afterwards insert a hook or two fingers (one) in there and pull towards herself along with what is already coming out.
Quod si os matricis coartatur, propter apostema calidum quod accidit ei: tunc non oportet ut laboretur super ipsum, imo oportet tunc administrare effusionem rerum humidarum, pinguium: et administra emplastra: et sedeat in aquis quae mollificant et humectant.	What if the mother'table is choked due to heat? I think it should not be allowed for her to labor over that; rather, at this time we ought to administer wet or warm substances with emplastrum and sit in water that moistens and soften.
Quod si foetus est super latus suum, tunc possibile est ut aequetur: tunc administretur quod diximus in foetu uiuo.	What if the fetus is on top of its back? Then it can easily be adjusted to position itself properly; at that time administer what we said before for an unchoked pregnancy.
Quod si non est possibile illud, tunc incidatur frustatim, et extrahatur.	What if it is not possible? Then proceed with the method described above and extract immediately.
Et oportet ut non dimittas aliquid ex secundina intus omnino.	It should be ensured that nothing from inside second stage continues to enter completely into her womb without interruption.
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc administra quod diximus in apostematibus calidis quae accidunt in matricibus.	When you have completed your operation, then provide what we said above for the application of heat strokes which happen to mothers.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc descendat in aquis stipticis, et administra reliquam curationem.	What if there is bleeding? Then it should flow into still waters and apply the leftover treatment. This indicates that medical intervention might be necessary to manage hemorrhaging during childbirth in ancient times, with water being used for immediate action while applying traditional remedies afterwards.
Et ego quidem iam uidi mulierem, in cuius uentre mortuus erat foetus: deinde impregnata est super ipsum uice alia, postea mortuus est foetus alius etiam.	And indeed I have seen a woman whose umbilical cord had carried a dead fetus; then it was pregnant with another one and after the death of this second fetus, yet another newborn has been born alive through that same uterine channel.
Accidit ergo ei post tempus longum apostema in umbilico suo, et inflatum est, donec apertum est: et coepit emittere pus.	Hence he fell into an extended time of suffering with his belly swollen and sore until it burst open; at that point, began to discharge pus.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius, et medicatus sum ei tempore longo: et non consolidatum est uulnus.	I was called then for his care and I treated him over a long time; but he did not recover any harm.
Posui ergo super ipsum ex quibusdam emplastris fortis attractionis: et exiuit ex loco os.	Therefore, having placed some potent plasters on him which had a strong pull; he went out of the place in question.
Deinde praeterierunt ei dies aliquot, et exiuit os aliud.	After several more days passed by, his other eye fell out too.
Miratus sum ergo inde, cum in uentre non sit os.	I was amazed then that there wasn't an organ where the umbilical cord had been attached within him.
Cogitaui ergo, quia erant ex ossibus foetus mortui.	Thought it therefore because they were a fetus dead in bones. The term "ossibus" typically refers to calcified remains or dense material like marrow rather than actual skeletal structure which would be rare and highly unlikely
Inquisiui ergo uulnus, et extraxi ossa multa, muliere existente in melioribus dispositionibus suis: et iam uixit taliter tempore longo, et mittit ex loco pus parum.	I searched for a male then from among the better positions of women; and I found many bones with her still alive after removing them all from their place; so that at last he had lived much longer time in those places than ever before, but finally let out only little pus.    
Et ego non firmaui hic hoc extraneum, nisi quoniam in eo est scientia, et adiutorium ad illud, quod administrat medicus artifex cum manu ex curatione.	And I did not hold this to be strange outside of it if there is knowledge involved and help for that which a medical tool used by hand in treatment provides assistance with its administration.    
¶ De formis Instrumentorum necessariorum in extractione foetus.	Concerning the necessary instruments required for fetal removal,   
Caput LXXVII.	Head seventy-seventh.    
Hic inferius est forma Strictorii, quo aequantur libri, cui aequaliter sunt duae uertigines in duabus extremitatibus duorum lignorum.	Here is the constriction form of strictures which equates books; and it has two thongs attached to its ends at opposing sides each fitting into one end of a pair of twin ropes.    
Verumtamen haec Vertigo oportet ut sit subtilior strictorio: et ut fiat, aut ex ebano, aut ex ligno bussi.	However, this rigidity must be subtle; and to ensure it is so, either of the following materials should suffice for its creation - from ebony or twig wood (bussery).   
Et sit latitudo omnis ligni quasi duo digiti: et margo cuiusque amborum est quasi digitus unus, et longitudo cuiusque eorum est palmus et medietas: et in medio duorum lignorum sunt duo additamenta ex genere eiusdem ligni, quae iam firmata sunt in utrisque, quorum longitudo est medietas palmi et plus parum: et latitudo utriusque est quasi duo digiti, aut plus parum.	And the length of each piece of wood is like two hands; and where there are four pieces in total (two uprights), one has a width equal to that of one hand, and its length is half a palm and less: and between these two woods there are additions from their own kind which have already been firmly placed on either side, whose combined thickness equals the middle part of a palm plus an even smaller amount. And both lengths are like two fingers or more petite.
Et ista duo additamenta intromittuntur in os matricis, ut aperiatur cum eis quando tu reuoluis duas Vertigines.	And these two additions enter into the mother's womb so that it opens when you roll out of bed with twin vertigo.

¶ De extractione Secundinae.	Concerning the removal of Secondus.
Caput LXXVIII.	Head seventy-eight.
Quando retinetur Secundina apud partum, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmae, ut retineat anhelitum suum.	When Secondus is with child, then it should be known that he must retain his sickness for the time being. (Note: This sentence suggests a belief from medieval times about pregnancy and illness which modern medical understanding would not agree with.)

Submerge these plant leaves with the help of water on top of a fire so that they may benefit from heat treatment too.

If then it shall have become attached to the deepest part of the womb (uterus), at that time apply her hand according to what we narrated, and continue until when Second finger has been initiated into this practice; gradually increase its application so as not forcibly fall back towards attachment by attraction: particularly it is necessary then, with ease on either right or left side of the womb (uterus): thereafter add in quantity to what we have explained.

¶ De curatione Ani non perforati.	Of the care of intact ants:

Nascuntur multi puerorum, et Ani eorum sunt non perforati, quos iam opilauit sifac subtile. This ancient practice suggests an appreciation for decorative adornment but does not imply any harm to those boys
Oportet ergo, ut obstetrix perforet illud sifac digito suo: et si non, perforet ipsum cum Spatumili acuto: et caueat lacertum, ne tangat eum.	It is therefore necessary for a midwife to pierce that slender digit of his own with an earring or similar object; and if she does not do so, then one should pierce it sharply with the Spathulin acute instrument: let care be taken lest the fish scales touch him. This directive seems to reflect a ceremonial aspect linked to body decoration in this culture (possibly referencing sea life), but also underscores concerns about safe and respectful practices for modifying one

Deinde cura ipsum cum ungentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until healed by mankind.

¶ De curatione Fistularum quae accidunt in inferiori parte.	From surgery of those fistulas occurring on the lower part.
Caput LXXX.	Head Eighty. "The Book" by Albucasis
Fistulae quae accidunt in inferiori, sunt Nodatio, et Grossitudo quae accidunt prope anum deforis: aut in spacio unius partium: et est Fistula una, aut plures.	Those fistulas occurring on the lower side are nodation and grossity that occur near a foot or leg below ground level; either within one section of space like an arm pit for example (fistula singly) or multiple ones together: these may be called Fistula singular.
Cum ergo antiquatur illa Nodatio, aperitur, et currit ex ea humiditas aquosa alba, aut pus subtile.	And therefore the old nodation opens and runs out of that liquid moisture or lightly flowing putrefaction..!!!
Et quandoque sunt ex istis Fistulis penetrantes.	Whenever there are such fistulas which perforate into it. (Here Albucasis refers to the rectum.) Certain kinds of inflammations
Ergo penetrantes cognoscuntur per illud quod egreditur ex egestione, et uentositate, quando utitur infirmus egestione: et fortasse egreditur ex eis uermis.	Therefore they know them by that which comes out through evacuation and urination when used in a weakened state of expulsion; sometimes even from the cough..!!!
Et sunt ex eis Fistulae quando sunt in spacio penetrantes usque ad uesicam, et usque ad meatum uirgae.	They are then fistulas when they perforate until the urine reaches up to a male's opening and sometimes even extending further..!!!
Et sunt ex eis penetrantes usque ad iuncturam coxae, et usque ad nodum caudae.	They are then perforating until it meets the joint of thighs or buttocks and even up to a tail node..!!!
Ex eo autem quo cognoscitur Fistula penetrans usque ad anum, etiam a non penetrante, est, ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum: et intromittas tentam subtilem in Fistulam ex aere, aut ferro: quando non est tortuositas.	But it is then called as perforating up to the foot even from that which does not penetrate; like when you insert your finger into one' endpoint and inserting tender lancets in there made of iron or lead, without any twists..!!!
Quod si in ea est tortuositas, tunc intromitte in eam tentam ex plumbo subtilem, aut pilum ex pilis equarum, donec sentias tentam, aut pilum in digito tuo.	If there is a twistiness in them, insert into it the gentle pressure of soft lead or an arrowhead from horses' arrows until you feel the thread or find the arrowhead in your finger.
Quod si non sentis ipsam penitus, neque procedit ex foramine aliquid ex egestione, neque uentositas, neque uermis sicut dixi: tunc scias, quia est non penetrans: propera ergo ad curationem.	If you do not feel it immediately straight away, neither comes anything out of the hole for evacuation nor pain, wailing as I told you was expected to happen: now you know that nothing has entered because it is non-penetrating; therefore turn your attention directly towards treatment.
Et quando Fistula est penetrans usque ad uesicam, aut ad meatum urinae: tunc significatio eius est exitus urinae ex ea, et prohibitio eius ab hoc ut consolidetur locus cum medicinis.	And when the fistula extends as far as to drain out urine or into a urethral opening: then its meaning is that there's an exit for urine from it, and thus this must be prohibited in order to consolidate the location with medical treatment.
Si uero est penetrans usque ad iuncturam coxae, aut ad os coxae: tunc signum eius est, quod perueniat tenta usque illuc, si non est in ea tortuositas usque ad os: et inuentio doloris in circumitu partis, et quod egreditur pus ex ea semper: et quod non ualeat in ea medicatio, neque consolidatur cum unguento.	If it extends as far as to the joint of your hip or thigh bone: then its sign is that through this wound will pass until you reach there if not twisted all way up to the pelvic region; and when I felt pain around the circumference, discovering pus constantly coming out from them always: which must neither be treated with medicine nor consolidated by ointment.
Et in istis Fistulis omnibus penetrantibus non est curatio omnino: et curatio earum est labor et uanitas ei, ex stultis medicis, super quem formatur.	And there is no treatment at all for these fistulas that have entered into them wherever they may be; and the only thing to do with those who are formed in foolish medicine (which thinks it can treat) above this: labor over its healing together with pain associated with it, resulting from their ignorance.
In illa autem quae non est penetrans, et non antiqua, speratur sanatio cum serro: secundum quod ego narro tibi, et ego iam probaui: et est, ut iaceat infirmus inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et eleua crura eius usque supra coxas ipsius, et coxae eius sint inclinatae ad uentrem ipsius.	In those that are not penetrated and also old or ancient ones is expected to heal with a sword: as I narrate this to you now and have proven it myself; let the sickly lie between your arms on their back, spreading out his legs until they reach above his own hips, while keeping them inclined towards urine.
Deinde intromittetentam plumbi, aut aeris, si est in Fistula tortuositas, donec scias ubi peruenit tenta.	Then insert soft lead or air into it if there is a twisted fistula until you feel where the thread ends.
Si autem sentit eam infirmus circa anum, tunc oportet ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum.	If he feels weak around his knee, then it is necessary for you to insert your finger into the knee.
Si ergo sentis in digito tuo tentam iam penetrasse per seipsam detectam, praeter quod sentias inter digitum tuum, et inter ipsum sifac, aut carnem: tunc ergo scias certe, quia est penetrans: non ergo labores in ea, quoniam non est eius sanatio, sicut diximus.	If then you feel with your finger already having passed through yourself and perhaps the body part as well (either muscle or flesh): at that time surely know for certain that it is penetrating: therefore no more efforts in vain should be made on this, since without healing purposes we have said so.
Dixerunt tamen, quia sanatur in quibusdam hominibus caro, et ex medicatione qua ei speratur iuuamentum, est, ut ignias cauterium subtile secundum amplitudinem Fistulae, sicut praecessit, et intromittas ipsum ignitum in Fistulam, donec perueniat circa anum.	However they said that some people are healed by their flesh and hope for improvement due to medicine: as indeed passed away the flame cauteratorily through its amplitude (the width of the fistula), inserted it into the Fistula itself, until when receded approximately at the knee.
Deinde itera illud bis, aut ter, donec scias, quia iam adustae sunt omnes illae carnes additae filtratae, quae sunt similes cannulae pennae auis.	Thereafter do this twice or thrice more so until you know that all the heated flesh on those pieces has been added with filtered sieve-like needles (similar to catheters). It is important not just for removing pus but also in reducing swelling and improving circulation. In medieval Latin, such a statement might emphasize not only physical cleaning of wounds or fistulas but perhaps an understanding that the inflamed body would be assisted by repeated interventions with heat (cauterization), which could
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, donec egrediantur illae carnes, quae adustae sunt: deinde cura illud cum unguentis generantibus carnem et consolidantibus.	Thereafter take care of it with ointments on the heated flesh until those pieces of flesh have come out (gone away): and then further care for that piece of skin, which has been inflamed but now is being cured: nourishing its substance as well as helping to consolidate. Si autem clisterizas eum in aegritudinibus solutionis uentris, et festinat exitus eius: tunc itera clistere, donec sanetur.	If you treat him with this enema during his illness and he passes out quickly afterwards; then repeat the treatment until he recovers.

Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	And this is the form for a subtle enema over what should have firm skin.

¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	Method for Incarnating Pulses.
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Take one part of the Olibani herb and mix two parts each of dragon'in blood (a mythical ingredient) as well as three non-extinguished calf tendons: stir thoroughly with much, beat it together, then apply to wounds; twist the bandage securely until firm attachment over the injury surface while mixing in a little blood.
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then tie it up above with silk threads and let go of it so that it does not stay attached while working on the wound as if nothing happened.
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	It is not eradicated by medicine until it has healed.
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	And whenever it makes a bandage alone, when you do not have frankincense in the present time, and blood of dragons also does this operation on many severe wounds with their own liquid, which was once air itself; so let them be bound above it firmly tied together.
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	If already another change has occurred in the air of this substance itself at least when it is summer time; then because its intent to heal ceases and since we have said before that you should let something be bound above or put on a poultice: so, do just as said. Alternatively, apply an ointment made from barley meal cooked in water with honey until pus is emitted; this will then cause it to heal.
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then tend the remaining wound care as previously instructed until they are healed.
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	If indeed a wound breaks through the bone and is not healed yet; then I will say about treating head injuries thereafter, for which it was destined to happen next.

And do not put anything cold on the nerve without reason completely: for since the substance of the nervous tissue is cold and its continuation with the brain (which belongs to more refined body parts) : it must be cared for gently, like marble covered in soft mud or warm oil mixed with water several times a day; and if necessary stones are used as well.

If the wound has already made an imprint in bone; then remove it carefully: if there are fragments of bone within it; take them all out or anything that you can make with these remains, but which is not prepared by hand and put into a pot for boiling. ¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	Concerns regarding pneumonia treatment in children include ensuring proper hydration (Zucheman) and managing fistulas if present

Scias, quod omne uulnus, aut apostema quando ueterascit et antiquatur, et fit ulcus, et non consolidatur, et emittit pus semper, et non abscinditur: tunc nominatur uniuersaliter in quocunque membro fuerit Fistula, et nos nominamus ipsum Zuchemen.	Sciences tell us that every wound, whether it be an ulcer as ancient and chronic (apostema quando ueterascit) or one fresh from a fall onto rough surfaces causing abrasion injury: results in ulcers which produce pus perpetually without resolution, then this is universally referred to whenever present within any member of the body. Herein we call such wounds Zuchemen and address them as fistulas for treatment purposes. This historical approach reflects an era when limited understanding dictated a broad categorization under 'fistula' regardless of specific origin or nature, underscoring the medical community’s evolving recognition and terminology relating to chronic ulcers that have yet not healed (non consolidatur) in children. Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore. This statement reflects an understanding within medieval medical practices that such interventions were subject to clinical judgment rather than rigid schedules. Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it should not be that children undergo bloodletting until they have reached forty years old.

Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Do not perform bloodletting on men who have lived for sixty years.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	Therefore, if someone wishes to undergo bloodletting for any reason, it is necessary that their bowels are cleansed prior with a mild enema before the phlebotomy, especially when stool remains within them afterward as harmful putrid substances: which should not be drawn into veins during excessive bleeding from intestinal overflow.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Do not let the patient undergo phlebotomy while experiencing true hunger or due to intoxication from drunkenness: until they have recovered their reasoned self-control and stability of mind.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Not even when suffering from hydrocephalus.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And the bloodletting may be repeated after colic pains due to passion (cramps), and in women, menstruation flow, urine discharge, multiple acts of sexual intercourse, labor, exercise, military service, sanitary work, fasting, all things which dissolve virility or strength from the body either corporally or animally.

¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	About Airs without scratching.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se. Caput II.	Chapter Two.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	It is necessary to begin this chapter with introductory sentences and chapters concerning which our thought turns first: namely the noble art of surgery above all others so that you may know it if ye are quick or prompt; and likewise for those who do not belong among us, but learn from within these walls.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	I declare that when an injury occurs to someone's bone fracture or dislocation or twist or any such case at the time it is necessary for them firstly to be blood-drawn and then treated, either by breaking up its substance, or both simultaneously; if there are no prohibitions like weakness of constitution due to diseases as well as that person who has fallen ill from these matters: whether he is a child suffering such an injury, or elderly decrepit man, or someone afflicted with sudden feverish heat without cold.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	Thereafter be satisfied with their own food, vegetables cooled in water and olive oil on the head and hands; prohibit wine, fatty meats, and repaying them from that which fills their veins, along with every other such sustenance filling up blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	When you feel secure from the hot stone's touch and not for a time, at that moment let him return to his weakened body; then he will recover on first returning to the customary regimen of his diet as usual.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	When therefore the broken bone begins to heal; at that time it is necessary for him to be fed with foods of great bulk and fatness in which there lies sweetness: such as barley bread boiled in water together with rice or wheat, along with cabbage leaves on his head and hands, legumes like lentils cooked with the same; whole-wheat pancakes made from flour mixed with olive oil and honey, fishes recently caught: red wine as thickly poured as possible. And meat of a large size in which there is plenty of fat to be digested together with substances similar thereto like those mentioned above; along with the consumption of butter or cream (as well) for flavor and nutrition, and milk from sheep's wool after it has been skimmed.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	Furthermore in such a regime the bone will also harden more quickly by blood congealing within it itself and better heal.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	You know that broken bones in men who are old and decrepit cannot be maintained or strengthened according to their nature always because of the weakening of those very members: but they should continue and harden as durable, like children's human skulls (bones).
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	However, nature connects the fractured bone with something resembling glue from all parts of it where there is swelling and adherence to itself until they are mixed together in a certain amount, which then becomes firmness and strength as before; for this reason we must put nutritious food that contains substances such as these.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	And I know that the species of fractures are diverse, according to the diversity of limbs: for there is a difference between crural (leg) and cephalic (head) bone fracture: and pectoral (chest) bone fracture, it differs from dorsal (back) bone fracture. Similarly, all other parts have their differences to each other in the amount required; and I come with this exposition of every species of fractures presented separately under its own chapter excepted for a few that are treated elsewhere or not at all mentioned herein: as they do not require treatment because it is evident from examination, so there would be no benefit. Moreover, those whose nature does not permit healing through the above means will receive an alternative form of therapy and nutrition to ensure proper care for these wounds, which are often accompanied by acute pain and bloating due to inflammation: as we have described in detail earlier on regarding their substance. Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And you know that when the bone arches and is split into two pieces besides where it has struck; but nevertheless all parts are drawn back together: at such time one must apply to have started from your own hour for its rectification, in equating itself beforehand as soon as possible while painful.

Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	And let your position be where you place the limb upon an equal spot according to its natural shape until such time as they extend the parts of the fractured member: then interpose a spike or hook (conare) in any way that with all ingenuity can turn back those additions; and so, if possible, along whatever space you have at your disposal by yourself: and caue according to courage, that pain does not happen over the weak person due to operation on him: nor injury. Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	And extend with vigor and compress hard as they do in the case of stones lodged within bones ('stolidorum').

Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	Thereafter attach after the bandaging (annectere post aequationem), and gently execute the treatment of that member again while maintaining its lengthening (decentem operationem) and keeping it stretched, as well as quietude: and reassure him who is ill.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua. ¶ De factura accidente in capite.	From the actual occurrence in the head. It's a phrase used by Albucasis referring to incidents he encountered or
Caput III.	Chapter Three, hereafter referenced as Caput III
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	The species of fractures are diverse and their forms many; moreover, the causes for them are different. It suggests that Albucasis acknowledged a range of bone injuries with various appearances in his surgical treatise on trepanning or cranial surgeries during medieval times.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	For there is a type of fracture that occurs due to impact with an instrument; and the blow causes not only injury to the bone but also perforates it as far down as possible, reaching into the interior substance underneath - this is called axial or spiral fracture. Albucasis characterizes such injuries by their distinctive pattern of damage that resembles an axe cutting through wood, which indicates a deep and twisted break in bone structure typically caused by rotational forces. This specific understanding would have been critical for treating cranial traumas accurately with the limited medical resources available during his time.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	Alternatively, there is a form of the blow where an instrument enters not just through the bone but also impacts its face and stops at the last part without reaching deeper into - this injury type gets named as kalaan fracture or leuation complete in Latin. This means that Albucasis identified cases when instruments like trepanatory tools accidentally caused superficial damage to external skull features rather than deeply penetrating, which he classified distinctly for treatment strategies and prognostic purposes based on the extent of fracture disruption observed during examination.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	And there are two kinds of fractures and a small one or large ones.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	And from the fracture is one that is crushing or grinding and its cause is by striking with a stone, or falling on a rock, or against similar stones:
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	And this fracture is also perforating, which approaches the clothing underneath bone and that is beneath the skull or on a face of bone: And such are two kinds of small fractures as well as large ones among them.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	And there is a fracture that lies hidden within the bone under fine hairs; and this kind of small perforation-type fracture in capillaries for its reason, it bears this name:
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	And from these there is a fracture which happens by striking with a stone and similar ones; and those make an incision in the bone to bring it into concavity: as when heated air enters through some opening, penetrates part of that inside, filling up its space.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	And indeed it mostly happens at the joints between moist bones, like those of children's heads:
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	And all these species are severed by blows and I end my remark on this whole topic:
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	And we know all these species of fractures through the observation and inquiry after them, along with their treatment to remove any harmful flesh on top:
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	And the capillary species is known through this way that it touches and removes from beneath while drawing up over itself with an inlay as if caulked or polished, making a dark-appearing fracture: for indeed there appears to be such because of its appearance.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	In curing fractures, first consider the injuries of patients; if you see something indicating a clear manifestation of fear due to this meaning that which is inflicted by an accident - such as cholera vomiting and epidemics in general or loss of intellect leading to memory's disappearance (amnesia), difficulty speaking, syncopal attacks with sudden stoppages like blackouts, fever acute enough for concern, discharge from eyesight, eye redness, likened by different accidents spreading about - which are untreatable: and if you see these signs do not terrify you or hope that it will be healed. Then begin the cure of such fractures.:
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	What must you do if someone comes to you with a wound that has become infected first thing in the morning: and it is necessary then to study how one should remove bone before forty days have passed, according to every single arrangement.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	And if it is during the summer days: then you must learn to remove bone before seven days have passed, before it gets dirty underneallearth and those misfortunate events that we describe occur naturally (without human error).
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	And if the bone has already fractured and is in contact with brain matter tangentially (and by minute movements or attraction): then it must be cauterized delicately as described to you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	And that is so with wounds bleeding from the head; remove any covering over it using whichever method you can manage: and according to its appearance and position above a weak part of the body (like an arm or leg).
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	And if blood flows from the bone fracture or you suffer a hot burn; at that time opposing it is what needs to be done according to this situation (no further actions are described).
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	And that is so by applying hot fomentations or oil rose petals under the skin in one spot and causing bleeding to stop until it becomes inflamed (further instructions are not provided).
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	Thereafter begin with treating bone fractures: remove the fragmented parts and heal them accordingly.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	It is so in accordance to two types (no further description provided).
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	Indeed one method exists where the bone with a sharp sword is cut directly at its edges and this forms how it should be done (no further details given).
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	Afterward, apply the surgical knife again after a previous incision made by an incisor sword has been done to little extent and this forms how it should be carried out (no additional information provided).
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	Then he also treats with a wider scalpel than before as well.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	And the second method is as follows: let there be with you a number of scalpels diverse in sizes; some larger than others and smaller ones also such that they are sharp at their tips and blunt below them. Let these last finally acquire an edge for sharpening, made by iron or bronze needles hammered (and use easily struck upon the scalpel). Thus you strike with it without hurting your head and injures itself.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	If the bone is strong and hard: then it needs to be drilled through its circumference before administering surgery with a scalpel; this being done when trephining (trepanation) without penetrating too deeply into brain matter, called Trebex which are not intended for drilling. And as the treble is rounded at that extreme edge of it below caput, and resembles an acute angle underneath along with a small circle prohibiting submerging beneath and passing through its thickness: therefore this procedure allows hammering upon the scalpel without injuring your head while harming itself.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	And you intend for it to accept from these trebles many numbers; each of which must match the density of bone present until every skull has a treble there: whose extremities acute amount in length and breadth according as quantity increases or decreases, correspondingly with that same degree of cranial bone's compactness.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	And this is the form of three species Treble or Scalpel: Albucasis also treats with a special scalpel wider than before for incising into hard bones and using an iron-pointed blade to make small
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	However the quality of piercing through bone to perforate a fracture is that you place Treble on top of the bone and strike with your own fingers until it becomes evident whether or not the bone has been penetrated.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	Thereafter transplant a worm to another place and put in what is the proportion between all the orifice size of bones' surfaces to their width.

¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	The restoration of a broken nose.
Caput IIII.	Chapter Four.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	Chapter Four: As for a nose that is not broken apart unless the two upper parts of it are both fractured at once (or one), this happens because these bones are indeed composed of just two bones; since below them lies cartilage, they do not break and will only suffer from attrition, curvature, and deviation.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	If one of the two upper parts is broken apart at that moment (then you must insert a digit in its nostril), and evenly bear down your index finger on it, along with pollice deforsi until this nose returns to its natural shape: let such art be performed easily.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	And lest any pain occur through your surgical intervention of it.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	And if the break is on top of the nose and does not return to its original shape by itself (then you need it leveled out so that there'd be only slight bulging at the tip).
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	If indeed a break is on both upper parts (at such time you should do likewise with its immediate restoration), and if the first day afterward's possible to repair it: then that must be done quickly as follows in general terms without special or particular details, for this case only.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	But if not possible on the seventh day afterward (or ten days at rest in warmth), let it be known when recovery is made and then start another attempt to set or repair with all due caution: provided there shall always remain a hope of success
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	Thereafter insert two small pieces of linen cloth into the extremity of the nose if there is a break on one side (or two such inserts if there are breaks in both upper parts): and let them be so large as to fill enough space within the nostril opening itself. These must be inserted very carefully with great caution, lest they cause any injury themselves or lead away from an effective treatment approach that would focus on aligning bone fragments for proper healing. The size of these inserts is crucial because if they are too small to fill a significant portion of the nostril opening (foramen Nasi), this technique may not provide sufficient external support necessary for realigning and stabilizing fractured nasal structures

¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	Concerning the restoration of the lower jaw when broken." ### Instruction: This is from a medieval Latin translation of an ancient Roman textbook on veterinary medicine by Aesculapius
Caput V.	In capite quinto, Galeni articula
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	In the fifth chapter of Galen's treatise on animal dissections, when the mandible is fractured but not with a bone fragment, and if it does not break into two parts due to injury from above alone: at that time, examination of its condition becomes easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	Therefore, it is fitting that if the mandible's fracture occurs on one side and not from below but above: at such time you are to introduce your left index finger into his/her skull; similarly for a broken jawbone in the right mandible insert the left hand’s palm inside. Also, gently press forward with this part of bone together with ease towards outside while using the other hand's flat side and push it until you get even alignment within both sides of that fracture (as much as possible).
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	If the jawbone's fracture has already been divided into two parts at that time, it becomes necessary to administer external reduction from both sides with due diligence until possible alignment is achieved (if feasible).
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	If at that time there occurs also pain or displacement in the teeth, then tie them gently with wax from which milk remains; alternatively silver wire or hair: and apply these materials to what still holds together until possible healing is achieved (if feasible).
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	Then put a broken jaw on its side.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	Thereafter place the doubled cloth over it and sew on one side of the large piece to form either an equal-sided triangular flap or patch from its length: that is for covering cuts upon soles similarly sized as a foot, but not extending beyond them.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes. Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	If you estimate that something is now changed or appears differently for some reason; then adjust it and place the same on its third day.

Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	While therefore keep that bandage on the wounded part; and do not let it go off until either it heals or is mended with a splint (or sutures): .
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	Often this bone breakage continues for three weeks: .
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	If then during that time an attack of intense fever occurs; apply to him frequently the thing which we have often mentioned before now about treating a hot boil: until he can remove it (from himself): .
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	And if there is also injury of some kind; take note and observe carefully the nature of that other wound or injuries as well.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	For now it is being taken off part of the bone (or teeth); then subtly bring you into this until those small bits are removed with what suits your treatment plan for removing them from their roots: .
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	If then the wound entrance is narrow and deep; expand it with a syringe according to its need: .
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	Then when you have removed it and nothing remains of it from them, its painful wound if large: place a bandage made up of materials that are applied to this over the part until healed.

¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	As for restoring a fracture in the chest wall, follow these instructions carefully ensuring minimal pain to patient with proper alignment of bone fragments
Caput VIII.	Chapter Eight:   
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	Whenever it breaks apart at its center, that happens rarely.
Extremitates eius quidem plurimum franguntur, et comminuuntur ex accidentibus eius.	Its extremities are often broken and crushed in accidents.

¶ De restauratione Costarum, quando franguntur.	Of restoring fractured ribs when they are broken.
Caput IX.	Chapter 9.
Scias, quod Costarum fractura non accidit, nisi in locis grossis quae sequuntur dorsum, et ex extremitatibus earum ab anteriori parte.	Section Scias IX. That rib breaks do not occur unless they are broken at the thick parts which follow the backbone and from their ends towards a part of the front side.
Et non accidit eis attritio, nisi propterea, quia sunt cartilaginosae.	And it does not break down because they are made of cartilage.
Et cognitio ipsius non occultatur sensui apud inquisitionem cum digitis.	Acknowledgment is given that the understanding of their sense cannot be hidden from an inquiry with fingers.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, ut aeques fracturam cum digitis secundum modum possibilem, donec aequetur figura, secundum quod oportet.	The restoration is thus made so that the equal rib break can be mended with fingers in such manner as possible until it takes an even shape according to what needs to happen.
Deinde emplastra, et stringe os fractum cum astella, si indiget illo.	Then perform a plaster wrap and bind the broken bone with splints if necessary.
Et si fractura Costarum est decliuis ad interiora: tunc accidit infirmo dolor uehemens, et punctura, sicut punctura illa quae accidit illi qui habet pleuresim: propterea, quod os pungit uelamen, et etiam ei accidit difficultas anhelitus, et tussis, et uomitus sanguinis multi: et haec est difficilis curationis.	And if the rib fracture is slight and inside: then it happens with mild painfulness and a puncture as follows - such that when an object pierces, for example, who has pleurisy (a condition causing sharp chest pains): because also this injures breathing; hence he experiences difficulty in breathing, coughs, and spitting blood among other things. This is difficult to treat.
Et iam ingeniati sunt antiqui in ea cum ingeniis multis: et ex eis sunt qui dicunt, ut ponas cibos infirmi qui generent inflammationem et uentositatem, ut inflammetur uenter, et extendatur, et impellatur fractura ad exteriora.	And there are also those among the ancients who say that they use foods to feed infirmities which generate fever and sweating in order to cause a bowel movement; by this means expansion of the colon is caused, it extends outwardly, pushing the fracture outside.
Nos uero abhorremus, ut non fiat caussa uelox ad faciendum apostema calidum, si non accidit.	We indeed despise such a cause as making hot applications to mend if not broken.
Si autem iam accidit, tunc addit in eo.	If it has happened already then at that time they include this too.

Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then let his hand be extended to the other side towards below (from one direction), and likewise stretch out his chest from this same opposite part with strength, so that he returns immediately back to where he was before: for it is not uncommon in people afflicted by some weakness of their limbs. This provides exercise as well as reassurance through the sensation of returning homeward while resting securely (a common medieval practice).

When something happens to him from it (the dislocation or fracture), and he undergoes a cure for the same, often death follows as well; therefore, it is not appropriate that anyone presumes over this type of care unless they are prudent in practice long-term use, merciful, pious, slow to act but also timely (not tardy) and neither brave nor reckless.
